generalfeedback.text: In order to solve this problem we will have to use the product rule calc_product_rule as follows: \[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}[@p@] &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle \left[\frac{d}{d@v@}(@pp1@)\right]\cdot @pp2@ + (@pp1@)\cdot \left[\frac{d}{d@v@}[@pp2@]\right] \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle (@diff(pp1,v)@)\cdot @pp2@ + (@pp1@)\cdot @diff(pp2,v)@ \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @diff(p,v)@ \end{array}\]

truefeedback.text: To differentiate a product use the rule \[\frac{d}{dx}[fg] = \frac{df}{dx}g+f\frac{dg}{dx}.\] You cannot get the derivative of a product by multiplying the derivatives.
You appear to have applied the product rule incorrectly. It is \[\frac{df}{dx}g+f\frac{dg}{dx},\] not \[f\frac{df}{dx}+g\frac{dg}{dx}.\]
The derivative of $\sin(x)$ is $\cos(x)$; you appear to have gained a minus sign which might suggest you have used $-\cos(x)$ as the derivative of $\sin(x)$.
